Award.AwardTitle: Engaging Engineers in Scholarship (EES) Fellows: A Scholarship Program for Engineering Freshmen and Transfer Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This EES Program builds upon the successful NSF-funded Computer Science, Engineering, and Mathematics Scholarship (CSEMS) Program. This scholars program provides financial and academic support to first-year engineering students and new transfer students from two year community colleges who are academically qualified and have unmet financial need, with special consideration given to women, racial/ethnic minorities and persons with disabilities. The fundamental objectives of EES are to increase: (1) the number of talented students with financial need earning undergraduate engineering degrees; (2) the number of underrepresented students earning undergraduate engineering degrees; and (3) the retention and graduation rates of students earning undergraduate engineering degrees. EES Fellows will have access to a specific set of support programs, called the EES Community, designed to support and enhance their academic success. EES Fellows will participate in academic advising and EES seminars focusing on professional and academic development and career planning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The A. James Clark School of Engineering at the University of Maryland received NSF funding support for Engaging Engineers in Scholarship (EES) Fellows: A Scholarship Program for Engineering Freshmen and Transfer Students.

EES Fellows had access to a specific set of support programs, called the EES Fellows Community, that were designed to support and enhance their academic success. EES Fellows participated in seminars focusing on resources, professional and academic development (first year, fall semester) and career planning and graduate school (first year, spring semester), academic advising and faculty mentoring.

The EES Program built upon the successful NSF-funded Computer Science, Engineering, and Mathematics (CSEM) Program. The EES Fellows program provided financial and academic support to first year engineering students and new transfer students from two year community colleges that were academically qualified and had unmet financial need from 2010-2015. The fundamental objectives of EES Fellows were met as follows:

1. Increase the number of talented engineers with financial need earning engineering degrees.

By the end of spring 2015, thirty-three (33) of the fifty-one (51) EES Fellows graduated from the A. James Clark School of Engineering with a Bachelor of Science degree in engineering (65%); fourteen (14) students are currently enrolled in engineering (27%). Of the four students that will not be earning engineering degrees, two transferred into other science disciplines and are currently enrolled (physics and environmental science).

2. Increase the number of underrepresented students earning undergraduate engineering degrees.

Twenty of the thirty-three EES Fellows that graduated are from traditionally underrepresented populations in engineering (African American/Black, Hispanic/Latino and female).

3. Increase retention and graduation rates of students earning undergraduate engineering degrees.

First Year Cohort Retention/Graduation: Twenty-eight EES Fellows came into engineering as new, first time freshmen. They have been retained at the following rates: 93% after 1 year, 93% after 2 years, 86% after 3 years. Of the students that are eligible to have graduated (12 students), 72% graduated after 4 years and 91% graduated after 5 years. These retention and graduation rates are higher those for the entire college (most recent retention rates for engineering are 90% after 1 year, 82% after 2 years, 78% after 3 years; most recent graduation rates for engineering are 52% after 4 years, 73% after 5 years and 75% after 6 years).

Transfer Cohort Retention/Graduation: Twenty-three EES Fellows came into engineering as community college transfer students. They have been retained at the following rate: 96% after 1 year. In terms of graduation, 35% graduated after two years and 96% graduated after three years. These retention and graduation rates are higher than that of other transfer students in engineering (most recent retention rates for engineering are 93% after 1 year; most recent graduation rates are 52% after 2 years and 89% after 3 years).


Last Modified: 10/29/2015
Modified by: Paige E Smith
